DOC.brief_summary: The purpose of this research is to investigate the non-opioid (non-narcotic) pain-relieving medications clonidine and gabapentin to see if they decrease the amount of opioid pain medications needed after surgery, thereby reducing opioid-related side effects, and time required to return to normal activities of daily living after surgery.
DOC.brief_title: Oral Clonidine & Gabapentin: Improving Recovery and Pain Management After Outpatient With Major Orthopedic Surgery
DOC.criteria: Patients scheduled to undergo arthroscopic joint surgery Willingness and ability to sign an informed consent document No allergies to clonidine, gabapentin, anesthetic or analgesic medications 18 80 years of age American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) Class I III adults of either sex Women of childbearing potential must be currently practicing an acceptable form of birth control, and have a negative urine pregnancy test Patients with known allergy, hypersensitivity or contraindications to clonidine, gabapentin, anesthetic or analgesic medications Patients with clinicallysignificant medical conditions, such as brain, heart, kidney, endocrine, or liver diseases, peptic ulcer disease or bleeding disorders Patients with chronic hypertension or pain syndromes receiving clonidine or gabapentin, respectively. Pregnant or lactating women Subjects with a history of alcohol or drug abuse within the past 3 months Patients taking any analgesic medications within 48 hours prior to the surgery Any other conditions or use of any medication which may interfere with the conduct of the study NonEnglish speakers Patients greater than 80 years of age
